'Macedonia' or 'Macedon' (from , {{lang|grc-Latn|MakedonÃ­a}}) was an ancient
Greek kingdom. The kingdom, centered in the northeastern part of the Greek
peninsula, was bordered by Epirus to the west,
Paeonia to the north, the region of Thrace to the east and Thessaly to the
south. The rise of Macedon, from a small kingdom at the periphery of Classical
Greek affairs, to one which came to dominate the entire Hellenic world, occurred
under the reign of Philip II. For a brief period, after the conquests of
Alexander the Great, it became the most powerful state in the world, controlling
a territory that included the former Persian empire, stretching as far as the
Indus River; at that time it inaugurated the Hellenistic period of Ancient Greek
civilization.
